text: Maj Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds of up to 95mph (153km/h) in bad weather before the smash on a B-road in Wiltshire. Gareth Hicks, 24, suffered fatal injuries when the van he was asleep in was hit by Mr Scott's Audi A6. Maj Scott denies a charge of causing death by careless driving. Prosecutor Charles Gabb alleged the defendant, from Green Lane in Shepperton, Surrey, had crossed the carriageway of the 60mph-limit B390 in Shrewton near Amesbury. The weather was "awful" and there was strong wind and rain, he told jurors. He said Mr Scott's car was described as "twitching" and "may have been aquaplaning" before striking the first vehicle; a BMW driven by Craig Reed. Mr Scott's Audi then returned to his side of the road but crossed the carriageway again before colliding head-on with a Ford Transit van in which Mr Hicks was a passenger, the court was told. Maj Richard Scott, 48, a decorated Air Force pilot, tragically lost his life in a training accident at the Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada on Tuesday. The incident occurred during a routine training exercise involving an F-16 Fighting Falcon jet. According to the Air Force, the cause of the accident is currently under investigation.Scott, a veteran of numerous combat missions, had served in the Air Force for over two decades. He was highly respected by his colleagues and known for his exceptional flying skills and leadership qualities."Maj Scott was an outstanding officer and a true asset to our nation," said Col James Thompson, the base commander. "His loss is deeply felt by everyone who had the privilege of knowing and working with him."The Air Force has stated that it will provide support to Scott's family during this difficult time and ensure a thorough investigation into the cause of the accident.

The ban was backed by local authorities in Urumqi, state media reported. The move is the latest in a campaign against Islamic clothing and symbols in the mainly Muslim region. China's government has blamed Uighur militants for several recent attacks - but activists say the violence has been fuelled by Chinese repression. The Uighurs traditionally practice a moderate form of Islam. Recently, though, the influence of stricter forms of the faith from the Gulf and Pakistan has led to more women covering their faces. According to the BBC's Asia Pacific editor, Charles Scanlon, the Chinese authorities regard wearing an Islamic face veil as an act of defiance at a time of growing violence in the region. In August this year, the northern city of Karamay banned men with long beards from boarding buses. Some experts believe such restrictions could backfire at a time when many Uighurs believe their culture is under attack. The controversial measure will prohibit the sale and distribution of single-use plastic bags in all retail stores and supermarkets statewide. Proponents of the ban argue that it will significantly reduce plastic waste and pollution, protecting marine life and the environment. They point to the success of similar bans in other states and countries in curbing plastic bag usage. However, opponents claim the ban places an undue burden on businesses and consumers, who will need to pay for reusable bags or go without. Some have raised concerns about the hygienic implications of reusable bags and the potential for cross-contamination of foods.The plastic bag ban is set to go into effect on January 1st of next year, giving retailers time to deplete current stocks and adapt to the new regulations. The state plans to launch an awareness campaign to educate the public about the upcoming changes.

"The wrong kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer saw Galilieo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only allowed to receive hay-feed or water before a race, but other substances such as electrolytes are permitted post-race. Employees of Palmer and fellow trainers, Francois Rohaut and and Jean-Claude Rouget, as well as the trainers themselves, were interviewed by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is yet to hear what punishment the BHA will hand down. "I imagine there will be a routine fine for a rule that's been broken," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. Palmer expects to be fully recovered from his knee injury in time for the upcoming season. The star quarterback has been diligently working on his rehabilitation program and is making significant progress. Palmer's medical team is confident that he will be able to participate in training camp and be ready for the season opener.Coach Kingsbury expressed his optimism about Palmer's recovery, stating, "We're pleased with the progress he's making and believe he'll be back to his old self when the season starts." The team has been supportive of Palmer throughout his recovery process, ensuring he has access to the best medical care and resources.Palmer's return is highly anticipated by fans and teammates alike. His leadership and skill on the field are crucial to the team's success. With Palmer back under center, the team is poised to make a strong run for the playoffs this season.

Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. But a disciplinary panel ruled contact with the pupil was probably made and her conduct had been "unacceptable". On Thursday, the Education Workforce Council imposed the suspension, saying: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again." Mrs Hungerford admitted shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager as he listened to rap music in her classroom - but always denied hitting his head. She was cleared, on appeal, of a criminal charge for assaulting the pupil during a maths lesson for those with learning difficulties. But in November, a disciplinary panel found, on the balance of probabilities, she had made physical conduct with the pupil on the head or hand. Regina Hungerford, 5, has become an overnight sensation after her heartwarming performance at her school's talent show. The kindergartener from Maple Grove Elementary School in Pleasantville, New York, took the stage with her ukulele and sang a rendition of "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" that left the audience in awe. Regina's parents, Mark and Lisa Hungerford, expressed their pride in their daughter's courage and talent. "She's always been a shy girl, but when she's on stage, she just lights up," said Lisa. The video of Regina's performance, posted on the school's social media pages, has gone viral, garnering over a million views in just two days. The school's principal, Dr. James Thompson, commended Regina's bravery and said, "She's an inspiration to all our students, showing them that with passion and dedication, they can achieve anything they set their minds to." Regina's future in music looks bright, and her family is excited to support her every step of the way.

She was speaking at an event on Thursday to remember four men who were shot dead by the SAS in her home village of Clonoe in 1992. DUP leader Arlene Foster said Mrs O'Neill was wrong to attend, but was not surprised. However, Mrs O'Neill has defended her decision to speak at the event. She said:"There are some who would say we have no right to remember or to honour them, we have absolutely every right. "Everyone, it doesn't matter who you are, has the right to remember their dead in a respectful and dignified manner." The four IRA men were shot dead after attacking Coalisland police station. Soldiers opened fire on them as they dumped a lorry used in the machine-gun attack in February 1992. The Ulster Unionist Party's Mid Ulster candidate, Sandra Overend, has criticised Mrs O'Neill for attending the event. "It is only to be expected that republicans would wish to remember their dead, but Michelle O'Neill's presence at such an event is hardly sending a signal to the unionist community that she is some kind of new departure for Sinn Fein," she said. Dr. Emily Thompson, a renowned environmental scientist, presented groundbreaking research that could potentially revolutionize the way we combat global warming. Her findings suggest that by implementing a combination of innovative technologies and sustainable practices, we could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 50% within the next decade. The audience, consisting of scientists, policymakers, and activists, listened intently as Dr. Thompson outlined her plan. She emphasized the need for immediate action and global cooperation to mitigate the devastating effects of climate change. Her speech received a standing ovation, and many attendees expressed their eagerness to collaborate with her team to bring these solutions to fruition. Dr. Thompson's work has ignited a spark of hope in the fight against one of the most pressing issues of our time.

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) said the force had "fragile" staffing levels and needed to "implement improvement plans rapidly". Inspectors visited the force after criticising its response to government spending cuts last year. Police and Crime Commissioner Olly Martins said the report was "out of date". In the HMIC's Policing in Austerity: Meeting the Challenge report last year, Bedfordshire Police was judged to be "requiring improvement". Inspectors, who said the force would be "monitored closely", returned in October and found it was not performing well compared to similar forces. It highlighted problems in the force control room, although said these should be improved by a recent increase in staff. The report described staffing levels as "fragile but improving" and said although there had been recruitment, it was not clear what investment the force had made in preventive work to reduce demand. "There is a concern that it may not be tackling longer-term issues," the report said. Inspectors said it needed to implement its plans for improving policing in "an affordable way more quickly" while ensuring its service "remains effective". However, they

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire & Rescue Services (HMICFRS) has released a report highlighting the need for significant improvements in the UK's police forces. The inspectorate found that while some progress has been made, there are still areas of concern, particularly in relation to the handling of domestic abuse cases and the treatment of vulnerable victims. The report emphasizes the importance of proper training for officers and the need for a more consistent approach across all forces. It also calls for better collaboration between the police and other agencies to ensure that victims receive the support they need. The inspectorate has made a series of recommendations, including the implementation of a national framework for dealing with domestic abuse cases and the establishment of specialist teams to handle such cases. The report comes at a time when public confidence in the police is under scrutiny, and the government has pledged to invest in improving policing standards.

Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of some 40,000 large black basalt columns which protrude from the sea. It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh then travelled to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He won a Victoria Cross for bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg was given the highest military award for valour after going out into the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled a statue of the soldier as well as a commemorative stone. His grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also gave a short address. From there, the Royal couple moved on to a reception at Portrush Golf Club as guests of the mayor for the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Afterwards, they took a journey back in time as

Their first stop on the cross-country road trip was a small, quaint town nestled in the heart of the mountains. As they stepped out of the car, the crisp mountain air filled their lungs, and the stunning scenery took their breath away. The town was a hidden gem, with charming shops, cozy cafes, and friendly locals who greeted them with warm smiles. They spent the day exploring the picturesque main street, sampling local delicacies, and taking in the breathtaking views from nearby hiking trails. As the sun began to set, they found themselves reluctant to leave this enchanting place, but they knew that many more adventures awaited them on their journey. With a newfound appreciation for the beauty of small-town America, they set off towards their next destination, eager to discover what other surprises the open road had in store for them.

The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the centre-left think tank in Sheffield. The government said extra funds were being given to early years providers to help children from poorer backgrounds and close the attainment gap. The report has also detailed a number of "tests" or benchmarks for the government's northern powerhouse scheme. Research by the IPPR showed only 47% of children born in the poorest families in the north of England achieved a good level of early years development compared with 59% in London. Its survey also found five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million) - but the IPPR forecasts demand for skilled workers in the North is set to increase. The IPPR has proposed 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's flagship policy to boost regional economies, including closing the "stark" gap in the development of children aged under five. The Institute of Public Health has released a new study highlighting the importance of regular exercise in maintaining overall well-being. The research, which involved a sample of 10,000 participants from various age groups and backgrounds, found that engaging in at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity per day can significantly reduce the risk of developing chronic diseases such as heart disease, diabetes, and certain types of cancer.The study also emphasized the mental health benefits of exercise, noting that participants who maintained a consistent fitness routine reported lower levels of stress, anxiety, and depression compared to those who led sedentary lifestyles. Dr. Sarah Johnson, lead researcher on the project, stated, "Our findings underscore the crucial role that physical activity plays in promoting both physical and mental health. We encourage everyone, regardless of age or fitness level, to incorporate regular exercise into their daily routines for optimal well-being."

North, 24, landed on the shores of a remote island after a harrowing journey across the ocean. The young adventurer had set out on a solo mission to explore uncharted territories and push the boundaries of human endurance. Armed with only a backpack filled with essential supplies and a determination to succeed, North navigated through treacherous waters and battled fierce storms. As he stepped foot on the pristine sandy beach, a sense of accomplishment washed over him. The island, untouched by civilization, presented a new challenge for the intrepid explorer. With a deep breath, North surveyed his surroundings, ready to uncover the secrets hidden within the lush jungle and towering cliffs. His journey had only just begun, but he knew that this moment would be etched in his memory forever. North's tale of courage and resilience would inspire generations of adventurers to follow in his footsteps and embrace the unknown.

Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. Rossouw, in his first season in county cricket, refused to say if his hand had been forced by Cricket South Africa. "Maybe, maybe not," he told BBC Sport. "I think that story is one I'm going to tell at a different time." Kolpak contracts allow sportsmen from countries with associate trade agreements with the European Union to be afforded the same right to free movement as EU citizens. They are not classed as overseas players under the terms of their contracts, but they become ineligible to represent their country at international level. Abbott and Rossouw's decisions came before Britain's exit from the European Union and they are among several South Africans to make the switch ahead of the new domestic season. Abbott's ability to consistently bowl at high speeds and generate significant movement off the pitch has caught the attention of selectors and fans alike. His recent five-wicket haul against India in a Test match showcased his skill and potential to become a key player for the Australian national team. With a strong domestic record and a growing reputation on the international stage, Abbott is being hailed as the next big thing in Australian cricket. Stephen Parnaby, Conservative leader of East Riding of Yorkshire Council, said the announcement was "great news for the town and the wider East Riding". The authority said it was spending about £100,000 on hosting the event. The organisers of last year's inaugural race said it brought £50m into the region's economy. The three-day event was launched by tourist body Welcome to Yorkshire after the county hosted the Tour de France Grand Depart in 2014. More than 1.2m people lined the 320-mile (515km) route. Mr Parnaby said last year's event had attracted thousands of spectators to the East Riding. "The council feels that the investment made by the authority, circa £100,000, to bring part of the race here is money well spent and will provide opportunities for local traders to capitalise on increased spending and help boost the East Riding economy," he said. Others in Beverley have also welcomed the race's arrival. Local amateur cyclist Ed Neilson said he hoped having the start of the race would encourage other cyclists to visit the town. Stephen Parnaby, Conservative leader of East Riding of Yorkshire Council, has announced his decision to step down from his role after serving for 17 years. Parnaby, who has been a councillor since 1999 and leader since 2006, cited personal reasons for his departure. During his tenure, he oversaw significant developments in the region, including the establishment of the Humber Enterprise Zone and the expansion of the Siemens Gamesa wind turbine factory in Hull. Parnaby's leadership has been praised for fostering economic growth and attracting investment to the area. His successor will be chosen by the Conservative group on the council in the coming weeks. Parnaby expressed his gratitude to his colleagues and the community for their support throughout his time as leader. As he prepares to leave office, Parnaby's legacy will be remembered for his dedication to promoting the interests of East Riding and its residents.Word count: 150

The next is a 24-hour strike planned for Wednesday, when emergency care will only be provided from 08:00 GMT. Asking by Marr about low morale among junior doctors, Mr Hunt said: "One of the reasons for that anger is that they were told by the BMA that their pay was going to be cut - it isn't. "They were told that they were going to be asked to work longer hours - they aren't," he added. "We are actually bringing down the hours that they work. The doctors' union has called for immediate action to address the growing crisis in the healthcare system. The union representatives have expressed their concerns over the increasing workload, inadequate staffing, and lack of resources in hospitals and clinics nationwide. They argue that these issues are not only affecting the well-being of medical professionals but also compromising patient care and safety.In a recent press conference, the union leaders demanded that the government allocate more funds to the healthcare sector to improve infrastructure, hire additional staff, and provide better compensation for doctors. They also urged the authorities to implement policies that would ensure a more balanced work-life balance for medical practitioners.The union's call for action has garnered support from various healthcare organizations and patient advocacy groups. The government is expected to respond to these demands in the coming weeks and work towards finding a sustainable solution to the ongoing healthcare crisis.

The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. As the South Korean company scrambles to contain the crisis, we look back at the developments so far: 2 August: Samsung unveils its latest flagship model Galaxy Note 7 amid great fanfare in New York. The phone is packed with new features like an iris scanner. The initial response is good and expectations high. It's seen as Samsung's big rival to the upcoming iPhone 7. 19 August: Sales start in 10 markets, including South Korea and the United States. European markets are scheduled for October. 24 August: The first report of a Note 7 device "exploding" appear in the news. It isn't long before there are more incidents with users posting pictures and videos of what they say are their phones overheating, exploding or catching fire. 2 September: Samsung announces a voluntary global recall of some 2.5 million Note 7 phones, citing faulty batteries.

The launch of what was supposed to be a groundbreaking new product turned out to be a major disappointment for tech enthusiasts worldwide. The highly anticipated device, which had been teased for months by the company, failed to live up to the hype surrounding its release. Critics quickly pointed out the product's lack of innovative features and its subpar performance compared to its competitors. Many consumers who had pre-ordered the device expressed their frustration on social media, with some even demanding refunds. The company's CEO released a statement acknowledging the concerns and promising to address the issues in future updates. However, the damage to the company's reputation may already be done, as its stock prices took a significant hit following the launch. As the tech industry continues to evolve at a rapid pace, companies must ensure that their products meet the ever-growing expectations of their customers to remain competitive in the market.

The removal of the engines, which have lain idle for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. Savings from the proposal would be invested in making more staff available to crew Fire Rescue Units. But the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) said it would be "dangerous and reckless" to get rid of them permanently. The London Fire Brigade (LFB) has released three plans to make the savings. It insists no stations will close and no firefighters will be forced to leave their jobs. The Brigade said it had continued to meet London-wide attendance time targets while the 13 engines had been out of service. It said that bringing them back would improve response times by about four seconds for the first engine to reach the scene. An alternative proposal has been put forward by London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore, who recommends putting the 13 fire engines back into service but making savings by establishing alternate crewing at stations with some specialist appliances. The removal of the e-scooters from city streets has sparked a heated debate among residents and local officials. The decision to ban the popular mode of transportation came after numerous complaints about safety concerns and reckless riding. Proponents of the ban argue that e-scooters pose a significant risk to pedestrians and riders alike, citing incidents of collisions and injuries. They also point out the clutter caused by haphazardly parked scooters on sidewalks and public spaces. On the other hand, supporters of e-scooters claim that they provide an eco-friendly and convenient alternative to cars, helping to reduce traffic congestion and carbon emissions. They suggest that better regulation and infrastructure, such as designated parking areas and clearer riding guidelines, could address the issues raised by critics. As the debate continues, the future of e-scooters in the city remains uncertain, with both sides passionately advocating for their positions.

The false message said: "Breaking: Two Explosions in the White House and Barack Obama is injured." US markets were spooked by the tweet; the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 150 points as it was retweeted. On Tuesday evening, the FBI said it was investigating the incident. White House spokesman Jay Carney told reporters soon after the tweet was published that President Obama was fine, and financial markets quickly recovered the lost ground. AP said later: "The @AP twitter account has been hacked. The tweet about an attack at the White House is false." The account was back online on Wednesday. The agency said the attack came after repeated attempts by hackers to steal the passwords of AP journalists, adding that it was working to correct the issue. Spokesman Paul Colford said the wire service had disabled other Twitter accounts following the attack and was working with the microblogging site to investigate the breach. Perth Sheriff Court was told there were three children in the car at the time of the incident. The 46-year-old was ordered to carry out 250 hours of unpaid work and banned from driving for two years. Prosecutor Rebecca Kynaston said motorists heading north near the House of Bruar shopping complex saw McCormack driving straight towards them. She said: "To their horror they saw the lorry coming south. He was on the wrong side of the road. "They managed to get off the road onto the verge. "The lorry missed them, but unfortunately it continued on and a couple with three children in their car weren't so lucky." Ms Kynaston said that the lorry hit the offside of the car and scraped along it. She said: "One might have hoped that would bring this to an end. John McCormack drove his battered old truck down the dusty country road, his mind preoccupied with the day's tasks ahead. As a seasoned farmer, he knew the importance of starting early and working hard to maintain his crops and livestock. The sun had barely risen, casting a golden glow across the vast fields that stretched out before him.As he approached the barn, John noticed something unusual. The door, which he always made sure to secure, was slightly ajar. Frowning, he parked the truck and cautiously made his way inside. To his surprise, he found a newborn calf lying in the hay, still wet from birth. Its mother, one of John's most reliable dairy cows, stood nearby, watching protectively.John smiled, realizing that despite the challenges he faced, moments like these made all the hard work worthwhile. He set about tending to the new addition to his farm family.

LG was one of the first smartphone makers to reveal it would feature the assistant on its new device, the G6. Google's update will starting rolling out this week to users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat installed. "With this update, hundreds of millions of Android users will now be able to try out the Google Assistant," said Gummi Hafsteinsson, product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. But other virtual assistants are out there. At the Mobile World Congress tech show in Barcelona, Lenovo Moto revealed that Amazon's Alexa assistant would be coming to the Moto Z phone. This will happen via an alternative back - known as a MotoMod - that Amazon will sell for the Moto Z later this year. And at the CES tech show in Las Vegas last month, Chinese tech giant Huawei announced it would include Amazon's rival Alexa assistant on its phones. Introducing "Google As," an advanced artificial intelligence system that takes virtual assistance to the next level. With its cutting-edge natural language processing and vast knowledge base, Google As can engage in more complex conversations and provide highly personalized recommendations. From managing your daily schedule to offering creative solutions for work projects, Google As adapts to your needs and preferences like never before. Geoffrey Stewart, 74, a retired engineer from Manchester, has embarked on a remarkable journey to raise awareness for Alzheimer's disease. He has organized a series of fundraising events, including a charity walk that attracted hundreds of participants from across the city. Unemployment fell to 1.69 million between January and March, down 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate remained at 5.1%, the ONS said. There were 31.58 million people in work, up 44,000 from the previous quarter. That took the employment rate to a record high of 74.2%. But the number of job vacancies dropped by 18,000 to 745,000, the ONS added, marking the first fall for almost a year. David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, said: "The employment rate has hit another record high, but this time the increase is quite modest. "With unemployment very little changed, that is further evidence the jobs market could be cooling off." Average earnings including bonuses rose 2% from a year earlier, up from 1.9% in the three months to February. The ONS said the timing of bonuses this year had affected the rise in total earnings. Excluding bonuses, earnings rose by 2.1% year-on-year in the three months to March, down from 2.2% in the three months to February. The number of people claiming jobless benefits fell by 2,400 in April

Unemployment fell to a record low of 3.5% in September, according to the latest report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This marks the lowest unemployment rate since 1969, signaling a strong and resilient job market despite concerns about a potential economic slowdown. The report also showed that the U.S. economy added 136,000 jobs in September, slightly below expectations but still a solid figure. The healthcare, professional and business services, and government sectors saw the most significant job gains. Wages also continued to grow, with average hourly earnings increasing by 2.9% compared to the previous year. The positive employment data suggests that the Federal Reserve may have room to further cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth without risking a spike in inflation. However, some economists caution that the ongoing trade tensions and global economic uncertainty could still impact the U.S. labor market in the coming months.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, with more than 5,000 tweets. In their posts, French social media users talk about films such as Total Recall, the title of both a 1990 and 2012 science fiction film. Total is also the name of a French multinational oil and gas company. Some users also changed film titles to reflect the shortage: Pulp Fiction was renamed Pump Friction, The Full Monty became The Fuel Monty and Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane replaced Mad Max: Fury Road. American actor Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood blockbusters attracted particular attention, with people inventing several titles for his Fast and Furious series: Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (translation: Not Fast But Furious), Immobile and Furious and Fuel Furious. Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to use its G20 presidency in 2017 to make progress. Mr Carney has previously warned of climate change risks for the finance industry. At the event on Thursday, Mr Carney said that in theory capital should flow from advanced to emerging economies due to high returns. In practice, however, the opposite has happened - and this has driven down bond yields in advanced economies, he said. When money has sporadically flowed to emerging economies it has had a destabilising influence, he said. "In this context, green finance is a major opportunity. By ensuring that capital flows finance long-term projects in countries where growth is most carbon intensive, financial stability can be promoted," he said. Mr Carney said the issuance of green bonds - for example, to help finance water or renewable power projects aimed at reducing carbon emissions - could double in 2016 from last year's $42bn. But they still represent only 1% of holdings by global financial institutions, he said. "The development of this new global asset class is

He emphasized that despite the challenges, the UK banking system remains resilient and well-prepared to support the economy through any potential downturn. However, Carney cautioned that a no-deal Brexit would likely lead to lower economic growth and higher inflation, forcing the central bank to reassess its monetary policy stance. The Governor also called for a smooth transition period to minimize disruption and maintain financial stability. As the October 31st Brexit deadline approaches, Carney urged the government to provide clarity on the future relationship between the UK and the European Union to help businesses and households make informed decisions and support the economy's long-term growth prospects.

The 2017 Nations Cup will be the first time Gabon has staged the finals by itself. The A320 pilot reported a technical issue with the aircraft's landing gear shortly after takeoff from London Heathrow Airport. The flight, bound for Paris, was forced to circle the airport for several hours while the crew attempted to resolve the problem. Passengers on board the plane described feeling anxious and concerned as they awaited news from the cockpit. Ground crews at Heathrow prepared for a potential emergency landing, with fire and rescue services on standby. After exhausting all possible solutions, the pilot made the decision to attempt a landing with the malfunctioning gear. Skillfully maneuvering the aircraft, the pilot successfully touched down on the runway, with sparks flying as the plane's belly scraped along the tarmac. The 150 passengers and six crew members were safely evacuated from the aircraft, with only minor injuries reported. The incident caused significant disruptions to air traffic at Heathrow, with numerous flights delayed or diverted.

A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than their two weeks statutory leave. The research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) blamed "ingrained" attitudes among employers, and concerns among new fathers that they could not afford to take leave. Last year the government announced plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave - changes are scheduled to come in April 2015. But the ILM said its research suggested the changes would have little impact if attitudes of employers were not addressed as well. "The introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to progress into senior roles," said Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive. "Yet our research revealed cultural barriers are impeding the uptake of both two weeks statutory paternity leave and additional paternity leave." He said there remained a "cultural expectation" within organisations that women rather than men will be the ones taking extended periods away from the workplace. The report also said low levels of paternity pay discouraged new fathers, with just 9% surveyed receiving more than two weeks on full pay. Responding

The survey provides valuable insights for the organization to address concerns and build upon its strengths moving forward.

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) said blood group O negative was vital, as it could be used for patients with other blood groups in an emergency. It said O negative blood made up 12% of transfers, although only 7% of people in the UK had that blood type. Meanwhile, B negative blood is needed for ethnic groups. The NHSBT said ethnic minority groups, who were more likely to have B negative blood, were more prone to sickle cell anaemia, where misshapen blood cells could block blood vessels, causing an early death. It also said such groups were more at risk of developing thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that hindered the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Only 2% of Britain's population were B negative, but hospitals had used 6% more of this blood type in the past last four weeks than the same period last year, said the NHSBT. NHS Blood and Transplant has issued an urgent appeal for blood donors, particularly those with O negative blood type, as stocks have reached critically low levels. The organization, responsible for managing blood and organ donations across England, reports that the current supply of O negative blood would last only two days, falling short of the ideal six-day stock level.O negative blood is particularly valuable as it can be given to patients with any blood type, making it essential for emergency situations and treating vulnerable individuals, such as newborns and pregnant women. The shortage has been attributed to a combination of factors, including the recent bank holiday, increased demand from hospitals, and a decline in donor numbers.NHS Blood and Transplant urges eligible donors to book appointments at their nearest donation centers to help replenish the diminishing stocks and ensure that life-saving blood products remain available for those in need.

Economists predict that the labor market will continue to strengthen throughout the year, but they also caution that factors such as inflation and supply chain disruptions could pose challenges. Overall, the current employment situation offers a glimmer of hope for workers and suggests that the economy is on the path to recovery.

Meanwhile, availability of Scottish temporary candidates declined at the quickest pace in nearly two years. The latest Markit Re port revealed a significant slowdown in the global manufacturing sector. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to a 15-month low, indicating a contraction in factory activity across major economies. The ongoing trade tensions, coupled with weakening demand and geopolitical uncertainties, have taken a toll on business confidence and investment. The report highlighted the challenges faced by manufacturers, particularly in the eurozone and China, where the PMI readings were below the crucial 50-point mark, signaling a decline in output. The United States, although still in expansion territory, experienced a notable deceleration in growth. Analysts warn that the prolonged trade disputes and the lack of clarity on Brexit could further dampen global economic prospects. As a result, central banks worldwide are expected to maintain accommodative monetary policies to support growth and mitigate the impact of the manufacturing slowdown on the broader economy.

On 30 January 1915, the first major naval engagement of World War I took place in the North Sea, off the coast of England. The Battle of Dogger Bank saw the British Grand Fleet, led by Vice Admiral David Beatty, intercept a German squadron commanded by Rear Admiral Franz von Hipper. The German force, consisting of three battlecruisers and one armored cruiser, had been raiding British fishing boats in the area. The British, with five battlecruisers and several light cruisers, engaged the Germans in a running battle. The superior speed and firepower of the British ships proved decisive, with the German armored cruiser Blücher sunk and two other ships heavily damaged. The British suffered no losses, although the battlecruiser Lion was hit several times. The battle demonstrated the effectiveness of the British naval strategy and the power of the modern battlecruiser, setting the stage for future naval engagements in the war.

A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch initial findings found the signaller believed there was enough space for both trains on the platform. About 35 people were injured. Read more on this story as it develops throughout the day on our Local Live pages The report said: "Allowing trains to share a platform is known as permissive working, and is allowed for passenger trains using platform six. "The signaller could see the rear of the train from the signal box window and estimated there was enough room for the moving train to fit on the platform. This was not the case." One of the trains was moved to platform six due to passenger lifts being closed for maintenance on alternative platforms, the report said. While approaching Plymouth, the moving train accelerated to about 21 mph and went through a relatively tight, left-hand curve. That is when the driver saw the rear of the stationary train on platform six and was surprised to see it so close to the west end of the platform.

Julia Knight, 56, de Montfort University's esteemed professor of mathematics, has been awarded the prestigious Fields Medal for her groundbreaking work in the field of geometric group theory. The International Mathematical Union recognized Knight's contributions to understanding the structure and properties of infinite groups, particularly her innovative approach to solving long-standing problems in the area.Knight's research has far-reaching implications for various branches of mathematics, including topology and algebra. Her work has also found applications in theoretical physics and computer science. Upon receiving the award, Knight expressed her gratitude and dedicated the honor to her colleagues and students who have supported her throughout her career.The Fields Medal, often regarded as the Nobel Prize of mathematics, is awarded every four years to mathematicians under the age of 40. Knight's achievement serves as an inspiration to aspiring mathematicians worldwide and highlights the importance of continued research in the field.

The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-II, also known as Nuri, successfully launched on June 21, 2022, marking a significant milestone for South Korea's space program. The rocket, developed by the Korea Aerospace Research Institute (KARI), carried a 1.5-ton dummy payload into low Earth orbit. This achievement makes South Korea the seventh country to launch a satellite weighing over one ton using its own technology. The success of the Nuri rocket comes after years of development and a failed attempt in October 2021. The three-stage rocket, standing at 47.2 meters tall, is powered by liquid-fuel engines and is designed to carry payloads of up to 1.5 tons into orbit. The launch demonstrates South Korea's growing capabilities in the space industry and paves the way for future missions, including the development of more advanced rockets and the exploration of the Moon.

Borrowing the names of famous celebrities for newly discovered species has become a growing trend among scientists. From beetles named after Leonardo DiCaprio to a spider named after David Bowie, researchers are finding creative ways to honor their favorite stars while also drawing attention to the importance of biodiversity. This practice not only adds a touch of humor to the scientific naming process but also helps raise awareness about the incredible variety of life on Earth. By associating these new species with well-known figures, scientists hope to engage the public and encourage a greater appreciation for the natural world. However, some critics argue that this trend could trivialize the seriousness of scientific discovery and distract from the real issues facing our planet's ecosystems. Regardless of the debate, it's clear that the intersection of science and celebrity culture has created a unique way to celebrate both the wonders of nature and the icons of our time.

The authors emphasize that failure to act could lead to widespread food shortages, price spikes, and social unrest, particularly in vulnerable regions. As the world grapples with the challenges posed by climate change, this report serves as a stark reminder of the need for concerted efforts to ensure a sustainable and secure food future for all.

The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the internet news group the Daily Beast two years ago. The Daily Beast's founder, Tina Brown, said its site now had more than 15 million unique visitors a month, a 70% increase on last year. She said in a statement: "Exiting print is an extremely difficult moment for all of us who love the romance of print and the unique weekly camaraderie of those hectic hours before the close on Friday night. By Ben ThompsonBusiness reporter, New York In 1933, Newsweek hit the news stands - a weekly magazine covering global events. But much like the world it's reported on over the last 80 years, much has changed in the publishing world too. Not least how consumers get their news. The number of Newsweek subscribers has slumped from more than 3 million at its peak to 1.5 million today. Couple that with falling advertising revenues for traditional print media and it's led Newsweek to ditch its print edition altogether. Newsweek Global, the digital only version, will be available via a subscription.

The final print edition, now a collector's item, serves as a testament to the publication's enduring impact on journalism and popular culture.

Charles Blackman's oeuvre is a testament to his unique artistic vision and his ability to capture the essence of the human experience. Born in Sydney in 1928, Blackman became one of Australia's most celebrated modernist painters. His works often featured dreamlike imagery, with a particular focus on the female figure and the mysteries of childhood. Blackman's most famous series, the "Alice in Wonderland" paintings, showcased his talent for blending reality and fantasy, creating a surreal world that captivated audiences. Throughout his career, Blackman experimented with various styles and techniques, from his early abstract works to his later, more figurative paintings. His contributions to the Australian art scene were recognized with numerous awards and exhibitions, cementing his status as one of the country's most influential artists. Today, Blackman's legacy lives on through his thought-provoking and emotionally charged works, which continue to inspire and engage art enthusiasts around the world.

The Spy Who Came In from the Cold is a classic espionage novel by British author John le Carré, published in 1963. The story follows Alec Leamas, a British agent who is sent on a mission to East Germany to infiltrate the intelligence apparatus of the Soviet Union. Leamas must navigate a complex web of deception, betrayal, and moral ambiguity as he attempts to carry out his mission and protect the people he cares about. The novel is known for its gritty realism and its exploration of the psychological toll that the life of a spy can take on an individual. Le Carré, who had worked as an intelligence officer himself, brings a level of authenticity to the story that sets it apart from other spy novels of the time. The Spy Who Came In from the Cold remains a landmark in the genre and a must-read for fans of espionage fiction.

OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other words on the technological endangered list are iPod, mp3 and Blackberry. In their place are iPhone, chat app WhatsApp and messaging site ooVoo.

OUP analysed more than 100 million words from various sources to determine the Oxford Children's Word of the Year for 2022. The chosen word, "queen," was found to be used three times more frequently than the previous year. This increase in usage is largely attributed to Queen Elizabeth II's Platinum Jubilee celebrations and her passing in September 2022. The analysis also revealed that children's language often reflects the significant events and changes happening in the world around them. The report highlights the impact of the late Queen's 70-year reign on younger generations and how her legacy continues to shape their vocabulary. Other words that saw a notable rise in usage include "royal," "monarch," and "crown." The Oxford Children's Word of the Year serves as a fascinating insight into the minds of young people and how they engage with current affairs through language.

Sterling rose 1.86% against the US dollar on Tuesday, reaching its highest level in a month, as investors welcomed positive economic data and a more stable political landscape in the United Kingdom. The pound's surge came after reports showed a rebound in UK manufacturing output and a stronger-than-expected performance in the services sector, easing concerns about the country's economic recovery. Additionally, the recent local elections in England and Wales, which saw the ruling Conservative Party maintain its stronghold, provided a sense of political stability that further bolstered investor confidence. The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of "buildings as power stations". The project involves Tata Steel, Swansea and Cardiff universities, and firms including BASF and Pilkington. More than half the funding is from the European Union. The technology being developed aims to enable homes, offices, shops and factories to generate, store and use their own solar energy. It involves creating innovative coatings for roofs, walls, steel and glass on buildings which can generate electricity. Scientists are also developing solar air collectors or steel "skins" which create cavities between the heated metal and the building to harness and store solar heat. They hope to create buildings which will not need a gas supply. One industrial unit in Port Talbot has already been generating all its own heat through solar power for the last three years. Kevin Bygate, chief executive of Specific said the potential was to deliver a "game changer" on energy: not only for buildings to become self-sufficient but for surplus energy to be stored and to supply the grid. Erika Murray, 31, was arrested and charged with fetal death concealment and witness intimidation after authorities discovered the remains of three infants in her squalid Massachusetts home. The grisly find came after a neighbor reported the living conditions of Murray's four children, aged 13, 10, 3, and 6 months, who were removed from the house by child welfare officials. Investigators later found the remains of three newborns, two dressed in diapers and onesies, and the third stuffed inside a backpack in Murray's bedroom closet. Prosecutors allege that Murray knowingly concealed the deaths of the infants, whose exact cause of death remains unknown pending further investigation. The disturbing case has shocked the community and raised questions about how the situation went unnoticed for so long. Murray is being held on $1 million bail and faces severe penalties if convicted of the charges against her.

She raised nearly 100 complaints about the treatment of patients, turned whistleblower and was a key witness at the Stafford Hospital public inquiry. She told the BBC she was "tremendously proud and honoured" to receive the OBE for services to the NHS, after what had been a "very difficult time personally and professionally". The care at Stafford Hospital has been the subject of intense scrutiny and criticism in recent years. The Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust, which ran the hospital, was found to have provided substandard care to patients between 2005 and 2009. An investigation revealed that the hospital had prioritized cost-cutting measures over patient welfare, leading to a shocking number of preventable deaths. Patients were left in soiled bedding, denied pain relief, and subjected to neglect and mistreatment. The scandal prompted a public inquiry, which resulted in the publication of the Francis Report in 2013. The report made numerous recommendations to improve patient safety and care quality across the NHS. The Stafford Hospital case serves as a stark reminder of the importance of prioritizing patient well-being and maintaining high standards of care in healthcare institutions. It has led to increased efforts to ensure that such failures do not occur again in the future.

It seemed too good to be true, but the mysterious device had appeared on people's doorsteps overnight, accompanied by a cryptic note promising the fulfillment of their wildest dreams. As news of the button spread, people began to experiment with its power, some wishing for wealth, others for love, and a few for world peace. However, as the consequences of their desires manifested, it became clear that the button's gifts came with a hidden price. Those who had wished for riches found themselves isolated and paranoid, while those who had sought love became obsessed and controlling. The world peace wishers discovered that the button's interpretation of their request was a chilling global silence. As society grappled with the aftermath of the button's influence, people began to question the true cost of getting everything they ever wanted.

Mr Higgins said the bank knew "exactly" the nature of the attack, but could not say more because it was part of a criminal investigation. The number given for the total population of the United States in the 2020 census was 331,449,281. This figure represents a 7.4% increase from the 2010 census, which recorded a population of 308,745,538. The growth rate over the past decade has slowed compared to previous decades, with the 2020 census showing the second-lowest decade growth rate in history, just above the 7.3% increase during the Great Depression in the 1930s. Despite the slowing growth rate, the United States remains the third most populous country in the world, behind China and India. The census data also reveals shifts in population distribution, with the South and West regions of the country experiencing the most significant growth. These population figures play a crucial role in determining congressional representation, federal funding allocation, and policy-making decisions that shape the future of the nation.

The woman repeatedly checked her phone, anxiously waiting for a message that never seemed to arrive. She had been sitting in the café for over an hour, nursing a lukewarm cup of coffee and trying to distract herself with the hustle and bustle of the busy street outside. As the minutes ticked by, her mind raced with possibilities, each more unsettling than the last. Had something happened to him? Was he simply running late, or had he changed his mind about meeting her altogether? The uncertainty gnawed at her, and she found herself unable to focus on anything else. Finally, with a heavy sigh, she gathered her belongings and stepped out into the chilly autumn air, resigned to the fact that the message she so desperately longed for would not come today. She walked away from the café, her heart heavy with disappointment and a lingering sense of unease.

A website polled users on their favorite ice cream flavors, and the results are in! The survey, conducted by the popular food blog "Tasty Treats," gathered responses from over 5,000 participants across the United States. Surprisingly, the classic flavor of vanilla topped the list, with 28% of respondents declaring it their go-to choice. Chocolate came in a close second at 25%, followed by mint chocolate chip at 15%. Other notable mentions included cookie dough, strawberry, and butter pecan. The poll also revealed some interesting regional preferences, with rocky road being more popular on the West Coast and pistachio ranking higher in the Northeast. This survey showcases the enduring popularity of traditional flavors while highlighting the diverse tastes of ice cream lovers nationwide. Whether you prefer a classic scoop or a more adventurous blend, there's no denying that ice cream remains a beloved treat for people of all ages.

Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales are taking part in a pilot scheme following the study. Coercive or controlling behaviour became a criminal offence last year. The research found that although most domestic abuse incidents were handled in a "professional" way, some officers still displayed "negative and uninformed" attitudes. In particular, police tended to neglect cases where suspects did not use violence but tried to control their victim in other ways such as by making threats. The report said: "A tendency for the police to focus on physical violence and what has occurred at the current incident can result in them missing abuse which is characterised not by physical violence and injury but by continuous coercion and control in other forms." The researchers concluded that if risk was not assessed properly some cases would "slip through the net". In response, the College of Policing is setting up a pilot scheme to help officers identify possible patterns of abusive behaviour. Research for the Collaborative Online Learning (COL) project has revealed promising results in enhancing student engagement and academic performance. The study, conducted by a team of educational experts, involved over 1,000 students from various backgrounds and disciplines. Participants were divided into two groups: one using traditional learning methods and the other utilizing the COL platform. The COL group demonstrated a 25% increase in student participation and a 15% improvement in overall grades compared to the traditional learning group. The platform's interactive features, such as real-time collaboration tools and personalized learning paths, were cited as key factors in the success of the COL approach. Researchers believe that the findings of this study could revolutionize the way educators approach online learning, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The COL project team plans to expand their research to include a wider range of educational institutions and subject areas in the near future.

Aiden Webb, 22, from Bristol, England, has been reported missing after attempting to climb Vietnam's highest mountain, Fansipan, alone. The experienced hiker began his ascent on June 3rd but failed to return from the solo trek. Local authorities and rescue teams have been searching the area since Webb's disappearance was reported by his girlfriend, Bluebell Baughan. Webb's family has launched a fundraising campaign to support the search efforts and has reached out to the British embassy for assistance. Fansipan, standing at 3,143 meters (10,312 feet), is a popular hiking destination in northwest Vietnam, but the terrain can be treacherous, especially during the rainy season. As the search continues, Webb's family and friends remain hopeful for his safe return. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of proper preparation and caution when undertaking outdoor adventures in unfamiliar territories.Word count: 140

The site is believed to have been a thriving ancient city, dating back to the 5th century BCE. Archaeologists have uncovered a wealth of artifacts and structures that provide insight into the daily lives of its inhabitants. The discovery of intricate pottery, well-preserved tools, and the remains of buildings suggest a sophisticated society with advanced craftsmanship and architectural skills.One of the most remarkable findings is a large central plaza, which likely served as a gathering place for religious ceremonies, markets, and social events. The presence of a complex irrigation system indicates that the city's residents had a deep understanding of water management, enabling them to cultivate crops in an otherwise arid region.As excavations continue, researchers hope to uncover more secrets about this ancient civilization, shedding light on its rise, fall, and the factors that contributed to its ultimate abandonment.

The Crawick Multiverse, a stunning land art project in Dumfries and Galloway, Scotland, has recently opened its doors to the public. Designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, the 55-acre site has been transformed into a cosmic landscape inspired by the universe's fundamental forces and the latest theories in cosmology. The artwork features a series of sculptural landforms, representing various celestial phenomena such as black holes, galaxies, and comets. Visitors can explore the site through a network of paths, bridges, and viewing platforms, immersing themselves in the awe-inspiring beauty of the cosmos. The Crawick Multiverse not only serves as a unique artistic experience but also aims to educate visitors about the wonders of the universe and the importance of preserving our planet. The European Challenge: Navigating the Post-Brexit LandscapeThe European Union faces a unique challenge in the wake of Brexit, as it seeks to maintain unity and stability among its remaining member states. The departure of the United Kingdom has not only altered the political and economic dynamics within the EU but has also raised questions about the future of the European project.As the EU navigates this uncharted territory, it must address concerns surrounding trade, immigration, and the potential for further fragmentation. Leaders must work to foster a sense of solidarity and common purpose among the 27 remaining member states, while also negotiating new trade agreements and partnerships with the UK.Despite the challenges posed by Brexit, the EU remains a powerful force on the global stage, with a combined economy that rivals that of the United States and China. By adapting to the new reality and embracing reform, the EU can emerge stronger and more resilient in the post-Brexit era.

Originally named, Glasshayes House, the mansion house on the edge of Lyndhurst was built in the early 19th Century as a private home for railway entrepreneur Charles Castleman. Along with Louis Stevenson, its notable historical guests included Lord Carnarvon of Highclere Castle. It later became the Grand Hotel, and then the Lyndhurst Park Hotel. The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, a historic landmark in the heart of Hampshire, has announced its permanent closure due to the devastating impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The iconic Victorian-era building, which has been a popular destination for tourists and locals alike for over a century, has struggled to stay afloat amid the global health crisis. The hotel's management released a statement expressing their deep regret and gratitude to their loyal patrons and dedicated staff. The closure of the Lyndhurst Park Hotel is a significant loss for the community, as it has been a cherished venue for weddings, conferences, and other special events. The building's future remains uncertain, but many hope that it will be preserved and repurposed in a way that honors its rich history and cultural significance. The closure serves as a stark reminder of the pandemic's far-reaching effects on the hospitality industry and the importance of supporting local businesses during these challenging times.
